All light craft sunk, damaged, and / or captured. | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Polish September Campaign}} }} The '''Battle of Hel''' ({{lang-pl|Obrona Helu}}, literally "the Defense of Hel") was a [[World War II]] engagement fought from 1 September to 2 October 1939 on the [[Hel Peninsula]], of the [[Baltic Sea]] coast, between invading German forces and defending Polish units during the German [[Invasion of Poland (1939)|invasion of Poland]] (also known in Polish historiography as the September Campaign). The defense of the [[Hel Peninsula]] took place around the [[Hel Fortified Area]], a system of [[Second Polish Republic|Polish]] [[fortification]]s that had been constructed in the 1930s near the [[interwar]] border with the German [[Third Reich]]. Beginning on 20 September 1939, after the Polish [[Armia Pomorze|Army Pomorze]] had been defeated in the [[Battle of Tuchola Forest]] and after other Polish coastal strongholds had [[Capitulation (surrender)|capitulated]] in the [[Battle of Westerplatte]], [[Battle of Gdynia]] and the [[Battle of Kępa Oksywska]], Hel was the only substantial pocket of Polish military resistance left in northern Poland. It was also the site of the invasion's only naval surface engagement. The Germans blockaded the defenders of the Hel Peninsula and did not launch major land operations until the end of September 1939. Some 2,800 Polish soldiers under [[Counter Admiral|Rear Admiral]] [[Włodzimierz Steyer]], part of the [[Land Coastal Defence]] formation, defended the Hel Fortified Area for about 32 days, until they surrendered{{Ref|date|b}} due to low supplies and morale. == Prelude == Construction of a Polish Navy port at [[Hel, Poland|Hel]], on the tip of the [[Hel Peninsula]], began in 1931,{{Cite web|url=https://www.naszbaltyk.com/wszystkie-kategorie/historia-artykuly/351-port-wojenny-w-helu.html|title=Port Wojenny w Helu|date=21 April 2013|website=www.naszbaltyk.com|publisher=Nasz Bałtyk – morskie czasopismo|language=Polish|trans-title=Military Port of Hel|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-09-17}}{{cite book|last=Śledziński|first=Kacper|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IMl-AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT63|title=Odwaga straceńców. Polscy bohaterowie wojny podwodnej|date=2 October 2013|publisher=Otwarte|isbn=9788324028566|page=63|language=pl|trans-title=Bravery of the Doomed. Polish Heroes of the Submarine Warfare}} and in 1936 the north section of the Hel Peninsula was officially declared the [[Hel Fortified Area]] (''Helski Rejon Umocniony'').{{cite book|last=|first=|title=Boje Polskie 1939–1945. Przewodnik Encyklopedyczny|publisher=Bellona|year=2009|isbn=9788311103573|editor-last=Komorowski|editor-first=Krzysztof|location=Warsaw|pages=121–124|language=Polish|trans-title=Poland's Battles, 1939–1945: an Encyclopedic Guide|chapter=Hel (1 IX-2 X 1939)|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XX5KcTNWbooC&pg=PA121}} Construction of the fortifications had not been finished before war broke out, but over several months, as tensions between [[Second Polish Republic|Poland]] and [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] had mounted, the fortifications had been reinforced with provisional earthworks.{{cite book|author=Derdej|first=Piotr|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=La5KfmIfGv8C&pg=PA57|title=Westerplatte, Oksywie, Hel 1939|publisher=Bellona|year=2009|isbn=9788311115859|location=Warsaw|pages=57–60|language=pl}} The Hel Fortified Area had coastal (anti-ship) and [[Anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft artillery batteries]]. The {{ill|Coastal Artillery Division|pl|Dywizjon Artylerii Nadbrzeżnej}}'s [[coastal battery|coastal batteries]] comprised one battery of four 152 mm (6-inch) guns, two older batteries of two 105 mm (4.1-inch) guns, and three batteries of eight 75 mm (3-inch) guns. The {{ill|2nd Naval Anti-aircraft Artillery Division|pl|2 Morski Dywizjon Artylerii Przeciwlotniczej}}'s anti-aircraft batteries were equipped with six 75 mm and eight 40 mm (1.6-inch) guns, seventeen machine guns, and two 120 cm (47-inch) searchlights. Infantry cover for the Hel Fortified Area was provided by a [[Border Defense Corps]] (''KOP'') unit – the {{ill|Hel KOP Battalion|pl|Batalion KOP „Hel"}} under Major {{ill|Jan Wiśniewski|pl|Jan Wiśniewski (major)}} – which had several artillery pieces (four 75 mm, and six 37 mm), sixty-two machine guns, and two large and nine small mortars. The Coastal Artillery Division was 162 soldiers strong, the 2nd Naval Anti-aircraft Artillery Division numbered 1,000 personnel, and the KOP battalion, 1,197. Overall command of the Hel Fortified Area was held by [[Counter Admiral|Rear Admiral]] [[Włodzimierz Steyer]]. However, Hel also became headquarters for the [[Polish Navy]]'s commander, Rear Admiral [[Józef Unrug]], who relocated his command center there on the eve of the invasion, on 31 August 1939, concluding that the Hel Fortified Area was better suited to prolonged defense than the more provisional defenses around his peacetime headquarters in [[Gdynia]]. Unrug also reinforced the Hel garrison with soldiers from his Gdynia garrison.{{cite book|author=Derdej|first=Piotr|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=La5KfmIfGv8C&pg=PA112|title=Westerplatte, Oksywie, Hel 1939|publisher=Bellona|year=2009|isbn=9788311115859|location=Warsaw|page=112|pages=|language=pl}} In September 1939, some 2,800 soldiers were stationed in the Hel Fortified Area.{{cite book|author=Williamson|first=David G.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wtg8a-0ggkEC&pg=PA68|title=Poland Betrayed: The Nazi-Soviet Invasions of 1939|publisher=Stackpole Books|year=2011|isbn=9780811708289|location=Mechanicsburg, PA|pages=68–69}} While the Hel coastal batteries were the strongest in Poland, they were inadequate to confront the [[Kriegsmarine|German Navy]] and posed no great threat to any of the German capital ships. Likewise, the Polish air-defense batteries in the region were too few and too light to deter enemy aircraft, and the [[Naval Air Squadron (Poland)|Naval Air Squadron]]'s planes tasked with defending the area, stationed at the nearby town of [[Puck, Poland|Puck]], were both older than their German counterparts and outnumbered by about ten to one. == Battle == [[File:Zatoka Pucka mapa mini.png|thumb|300px|Map of [[Hel Peninsula]]. The town of [[Hel, Poland|Hel]] is at the Peninsula's tip.]] Hel was attacked by the German [[Luftwaffe]] from the first day of the invasion.{{cite book|author=Commager|first=Henry Steele|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p19SCD47zwQC&pg=PA16|title=The Story of the Second World War|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|year=2004|isbn=9781574887419|location=Sterling, VA|pages=16–19}} The first air raid occurred at 13:30, 1 September 1939, targeting the Polish coastal batteries. The second air raid, the same day at 18:00, targeted ships in the port, damaging the Polish light [[minelayer]] ORP ''[[ORP Mewa|Mewa]]''. Further air raids occurred the following day. On 3 September, the Polish destroyer ORP ''[[ORP Wicher (1928)|Wicher]]'' and large minelayer ORP ''[[ORP Gryf (1936)|Gryf]]'', supported by Polish coastal-battery fire, engaged two German [[destroyer]]s, [[German destroyer Z1 Leberecht Maass|''Z1 Leberecht Maass'']] and [[German destroyer Z9 Wolfgang Zenker|''Z9 Wolfgang Zenker'']].{{cite book|author1=Kaufmann|first=J.E.|last-author-amp=yes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gmw0ngEACAAJ&pg=PA272|title=Fortress Europe: European Fortifications of World War II|author2=Jurga|first2=Robert M.|author3=Kaufmann|first3=E.|date=21 July 2009|publisher=Da Capo Press, Incorporated|year=|isbn=9780786749874|location=Boston, MA|page=272|pages=}} The Polish coastal battery also participated in this battle. This was the only surface naval engagement of the September Campaign and was relatively inconsequential. The German destroyer ''Z1 Leberecht Maass'' sustained light damage and four fatalities.{{cite book|author=Whitley|first=M. J.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xQDzAAAAMAAJ|title=German Destroyers of World War Two|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=1991|isbn=9781557503022|location=Annapolis, MD|pages=83–85}}{{cite book|author1=Koop|first=Gerhard |last-author-amp=yes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rYzPBQAAQBAJ|title=German Destroyers of World War II: Warships of the Kriegsmarine|author2=Schmolke|first2=Klaus-Peter|date=22 July 2014|publisher=Seaforth Publishing|year=|isbn=9781848321939|location=Barnsley|page=78|pages=}} The Polish ''Gryf'' also sustained light damage, with seven fatalities.{{cite book|author=Pertek|first=Jerzy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HvufAAAAMAAJ|title=Mała flota wielka duchem|publisher=Wydawnictwo Poznańskie|year=1989|isbn=9788321006970|location=Poznań|pages=512–513|language=Polish|trans-title=Small Fleet with Big Spirit}} The German ships retreated, and later that day the Luftwaffe sank the ORP ''Gryf'', the ORP ''Wicher'', as well as the ORP ''Mewa'', the Polish [[gunboat]] ORP ''[[ORP General Haller|General Haller]]'' sustained heavy damage, was abandoned, and sank on 6 September.{{cite magazine|first=Marek|last=Twardowski|title=Kanonierki Generał Haller i Komendant Piłsudski|trans-title=Gunboats Generał Haller and Komendant Piłsudski|magazine=Morza Statki i Okręty|date=1998|issn=1426-529X |language=Polish|pages=19–22|volume=3|issue=10}} The Polish gunboat ORP ''[[ORP Komendant Piłsudski|Komendant Piłsudski]]'', though largely undamaged, was also abandoned. This effectively eliminated the already heavily outnumbered surface Polish Navy as a fighting force on the [[Baltic Sea]], with only several light units remaining operational in the theater.{{Ref|largeships|c}} The surviving crews of the sunken Polish vessels joined the garrison's defenders, and two 120 mm guns from ORP ''Gryf'' were salvaged for shore-battery use.{{cite book|author=Zaloga|first=Steven J.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W8Q-vgAACAAJ|title=Poland 1939: The birth of Blitzkrieg|date=19 August 2002|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|year=|isbn=9781841764085|location=London|page=39|pages=}} In the first week of September, the [[Wehrmacht]] forced Polish [[Armia Pomorze]] units to retreat from the [[Danzig Corridor]] and, having captured Puck, on 9 September began assaulting the Polish forces on the Hel Peninsula. The advancing German forces included the 42nd Border Guard Regiment and the 5th Cavalry Regiment. Polish forces started a slow retreat toward the port of Hel on the Peninsula. On 10 September the Germans captured the village of [[Swarzewo]], and on 11 September the town of [[Władysławowo]] near the base of the Peninsula. The Polish defenders fortified the next village, [[Chałupy]], about a fifth of the way up the Peninsula. The Germans, having bottled up the Polish units on the Peninsula, did not launch major land operations until month's end. On the night of 12/13 September 1939, the remaining Polish light minelayers laid a [[minefield]] near Hel. The following day, the Luftwaffe sank the Polish light minelayers ORP ''[[ORP Jaskółka|Jaskółka]]'' and ORP ''[[ORP Czapla|Czapla]]'' at the port of [[Jastarnia]], while the remaining minelayers, ORP ''[[ORP Czajka|Czajka]], [[ORP Rybitwa|Rybitwa]]'', and ORP ''[[ORP Żuraw|Żuraw]]'', were damaged. In view of German superiority on the Baltic Sea, the remaining Polish naval units docked at the Hel port and their crews joined the ground forces.{{cite journal|last=Twardowski|first=Marek|date=1999|title=Pod trzema banderami: Dzieje trałowców typu Jaskółka|trans-title=Under Three Banners: The Story of Jaskółka-tyle Minesweepers|url=|journal=Morza, Statki I Okręty|language=pl|volume=6|pages=|issn=1426-529X|via=}} The ships' armaments were stripped and converted into additional land-gun emplacements. Heavier German naval units, namely the old [[Deutschland-class battleship]]s {{SMS|Schleswig-Holstein||2}} and {{SMS|Schlesien||2}}, shelled the Hel Peninsula, to little effect. ''Schleswig-Holstein'' began shelling Polish positions at Hel and [[Redłowo]] (on the other side of the [[Vistula Lagoon]], site of the [[battle of Gdynia]]) after the surrendered the Polish garrison at [[Westerplatte]] on 7 September. These operations lasted until 13 September.{{cite book|last=Rohwer|first=Jürgen|title=Chronology of the War at Sea, 1939–1945: The Naval History of World War Two|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=2005|isbn=9781591141198|location=Annapolis, MD|pages=4–5|ref={{sfnRef|Rohwer}}|authorlink=Jürgen Rohwer}} ''Schlesien'' returned to bombarding Polish positions at Jastarnia and Hel from September 21.{{cite book|last1=Hildebrand|first1=Hans H.|title=Die Deutschen Kriegsschiffe: Biographien: ein Spiegel der Marinegeschichte von 1815 bis zur Gegenwart (Band 7)|last2=Röhr|first2=Albert|last3=Steinmetz|first3=Hans-Otto|publisher=Mundus Verlag|year=1993|isbn=9783782202671|location=Ratingen|page=128|pages=|language=German|trans-title=The German Warships: Biographies: A Reflection of Naval History from 1815 to the Present (Volume 7)|ref={{sfnRef|Hildebrand, Röhr, & Steinmetz Vol. 7}}|lastauthoramp=y}} Between 25 and 27 September, the ''Schleswig-Holstein'' joined her sister ship at Hel again. On 25 September it was lightly damaged by Polish coastal batteries. Throughout that time, a number of air raids targeted the Hel Fortified Area as well. The Polish [[anti-aircraft]] batteries proved highly effective, shooting down between 46 and 53 German aircraft. [[Henry Steele Commager]] writes that the Germans, after initially being stalled by Polish defenses, brought up land-artillery batteries and an [[armored train]] battery to support their barrage. According to Commager, German forces slowly advanced, still facing substantial resistance and [[counterattack]]s, and on 25 September, after the Germans took the village of [[Chałupy]], Polish military engineers detonated [[torpedo]] warheads at the Peninsula's narrowest part, temporarily transforming the Peninsula's far end into an island. [[File:Dzialo 75 mm Bateria plot. Hel.jpg|thumb|left|Polish 75 mm [[anti-aircraft gun]] at the Battle of Hel]] A somewhat different account appears in the Polish-language ''Poland's Battles, 1939–1945: an Encyclopedic Guide'', edited by {{ill|Krzysztof Komorowski|pl|Krzysztof Komorowski (historyk) }}. The chapter on the Battle of Hel states that no substantial land engagements took place until 28 September, when German units slowly advanced toward Chałupy. In this account, the major German push took place on 30 September 1939. The German units assigned to take Hel, the 374th Infantry Regiment and the 207th Light Artillery Regiment, captured Chałupy on 30 September, and shortly afterward the Poles detonated the torpedo warheads – but the resulting damage was "less than expected", though it wrecked the Peninsula's railroad line. On 1 October 1939 the [[Polish Navy]]'s commander, Rear Admiral Józef Unrug, taking into account that the Polish outpost was running out of supplies and that no relief force would be coming, and in view of low troop morale, with two mutiny attempts having been quelled on 29 and 30 September, gave orders to [[Capitulation (surrender)|capitulate]]. Some Polish soldiers attempted to flee across the Baltic Sea to [[Sweden]] on the remaining light craft and civilian vessels, but most were unsuccessful. The Germans occupied the Hel Peninsula by 2 October.{{cite book|author=Derdej|first=Piotr|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=La5KfmIfGv8C&pg=PA186|title=Westerplatte, Oksywie, Hel 1939|publisher=Bellona|year=2009|isbn=9788311115859|location=Warsaw|page=186|pages=|language=}} Some accounts of the Battle of Hel report the sinking on 1 October of the German minesweeper [[SMS M85|''M85'']] by a mine near the Hel Peninsula, with 24 fatalities. The minefield had been laid by the Polish submarine ORP ''[[ORP Żbik|Żbik]]'' as part of [[Worek Plan|Plan Sack]]. ORP ''Żbik'' and two other submarines, ORP ''[[ORP Sęp (1938)|Sęp]]'' and ORP ''[[ORP Ryś|Ryś]]'' – stationed at Hel – had gone to sea on 1 September.{{cite book|last=Haarr|first=Geirr H.|title=The Gathering Storm: The Naval War in Northern Europe: September 1939 – April 1940|publisher=Seaforth|year=2013|isbn=9781848321403|location=Barnsley|pp=50, 52, 55}}{{cite book|author1=Zaloga|first=Steve |last-author-amp=yes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L1EpAQAAMAAJ|title=The Polish Campaign, 1939|author2=Madej|first2=W. Victor|date=31 December 1990|publisher=Hippocrene Books|year=|isbn=9780870520136|location=New York, NY|page=143|pages=}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DFU3AAAAIAAJ|title=Kampania wrzesniowa 1939 r. na morzu w świetle prawa międzynarodowego|last=Ordon|first=Stanisław|publisher=Wydawnictwo Morskie|year=1963|page=70|language=Polish|trans-title=September Campaign of 1939 in the Sea in Light of International Law}} == Aftermath == [[File:Hel kapitulacja 01.jpg|thumb|Capitulation of Hel, 1 or 2 October 1939. Polish Commodore [[Stefan Frankowski]] ''(right)'', German Admiral [[Hubert Schmundt]] ''(left)'']] Polish battle casualties were light – some 50 dead and 150 wounded. About 3,600 Polish soldiers and sailors were taken prisoner. German losses were similar, estimated at a few dozen dead and wounded.{{Ref|Casualties|d}} Some remaining Polish light vessels, including light minelayers, gunboats, and noncombatant units such as tugboats, which were not sunk by air raids, may (sources vary) have been [[scuttled]] before the capitulation. Either way, most were either captured by the Germans or raised from the shallow waters and pressed into German service in subsequent weeks. After Hel's surrender, the only organized military resistance in Poland was conducted by [[Independent Operational Group Polesie]], which capitulated after the [[Battle of Kock (1939)|Battle of Kock]] on 5 October 1939, marking the end of organized resistance to the German invasion.{{cite book|author=Zaloga|first=Steve|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IXshAQAAIAAJ|title=Poland 1939: The Birth of Blitzkrieg|publisher=Praeger|year=2002|isbn=9780275982782|location=Santa Barbara, CA|pages=12, 84}} Some of the fortifications of Hel survived, and are currently tourist attractions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hel.pl/artykul_rejon-umocniony-hel-8211-zabytki-militarne-na-helu.php|title=Hel (Półwysep Helski) Rejon Umocniony Hel – zabytki militarne na Helu|website=www.hel.pl|language=en|trans-title=Hel (Hel Peninsula) Fortified Region Hel – Military Objects of Cultural Heritage at Hel|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-09-17}} One of Hel's four 152 mm [[Bofors]] batteries is now on display at the [[Polish Army Museum]] in Warsaw.{{cite book|author=Zaloga|first=Steven J.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W8Q-vgAACAAJ|title=Poland 1939: The birth of Blitzkrieg|date=19 August 2002|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|year=|isbn=9781841764085|location=London|page=59|pages=}} The Battle of Hel appears among the battles inscribed on the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Warsaw)|Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.solidarnosc.gda.pl/aktualnosci/wybrzeze-w-1939-roku-bronilo-sie-z-honorem-ostatniego-naboju/|title=Wybrzeże w 1939 roku broniło się z honorem do ostatniego naboju|date=2019-09-23|website=Region Gdański NSZZ „Solidarność"|language=pl-PL|trans-title=The Coast Defended Itself with Honor to the Last Bullet in 1939|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-09-25}} == Notes == {{reflist|group=Note}} * {{note|Number}} This includes troops initially deployed at the [[Battle of Kępa Oksywska]]. * {{note|date}} [[capitulation (surrender)|Capitulation]] negotiations began the night of 30 September/1 October 1939. [[Ceasefire]] orders were issued the following day, and on 2 October 1939 the Polish troops were taken [[prisoner of war|prisoner-of-war]] by the German force that occupied the Region. * {{note|largeships}} Three other large surface ships of the Polish Navy, destroyers {{ORP|Błyskawica}}, {{ORP|Burza}} and {{ORP|Grom|1936|6}}, were successfully evacuated shortly before the war started to British ports, following the contingency [[Peking Plan]].{{cite book|author=Haarr|first=Geirr H.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pNw7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA45|title=The Gathering Storm: The Naval War in Northern Europe September 1939 – April 1940|date=24 September 2013|publisher=Seaforth Publishing|year=|isbn=9781848321403|location=Barnsley|pages=45–46}} * {{note|Casualties}} It is unclear whether these estimates include any fatalities among German aircraft personnel downed by Hel air defenses, or fatalities among naval personnel on the two sides. German destroyer ''Z1'' suffered 4 dead and 4 wounded in the engagement with Hel defenders on 3 September. Polish minelayer ''Gryf'' suffered 7 fatalities during the naval engagement. All Polish naval units also suffered some further fatalities from the air raids. German minesweeper ''M85'' was sunk on a nearby minefield with 24 fatalities. == References == {{Commons category|Siege of Hel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hel}} [[Category:Battles of the Invasion of Poland]] [[Category:Naval battles of World War II involving Poland]] [[Category:Sieges involving Germany]] [[Category:Sieges involving Poland]] [[Category:Pomeranian Voivodeship (1919–1939)]] [[Category:September 1939 events]] [[Category:October 1939 events]]
